title: Restrict/unrestrict user login
text:
To restrict user login:

sudo usermod -s /usr/sbin/nologin username

Check if the user has been restricted:

sudo su - username
It will show a message similar to the following:
This account is currently not available.

To unrestrict user login:

sudo usermod -s /bin/bash username

title: Remove read access to other users
text:
To prevent other users from reading a user’s data:

sudo chmod 700 /home/username

Check if the access is restricted:

ls /home/username
It will show a message similar to the following:
ls: cannot open directory '/home/username': Permission denied

To apply this restriction to all existing users, run the following command:

sudo chmod 700 /home/*

All sudo users can still access the contents of the home directories of their own as well as others.

title: Remove read access to other users
section: How to set this by default for all new user accounts?
text:
How to set this by default for all new user accounts?
A solution is given here.
We can simply change the DIR_MODE in /etc/adduser.conf file to this:
DIR_MODE=0700
# DIR_MODE=0755  # This is default
Where: - 0 means octal numbering system. - 7 means read (4) + write (2) + execute (1) access to the owner. - Last two zeros means no access to other users.

text:
Setup

At the time of writing, we have a QNAP NAS with 6 HDDs with 16 TB storage space each. The total storage space is 96 TB. The NAS is connected to the network and is accessible via the IP address 10.0.62.201.
I want to try with two HDDs first in RAID 1 configuration. I will add more HDDs later. So, this amounts to total 16 TB storage space with 1 hard-disk failure tolerance.
